issue.title: [R] Improve the R-only development guide
issue.body:
***Note**: This issue was originally created as [ARROW-14371](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14371). Please see the [migration documentation](https://gist.github.com/toddfarmer/12aa88361532d21902818a6044fda4c3) for further details.*

### Original Issue Description:
There are a few ways we could make the R-only development guide better (this list isn't exhaustive, but are things that have come up in the discussion here):

- A note that the brew-based method and the build-your-own methods are incompatible (mostly because of `ARROW_HOME`, but folks using brew shouldn't need to even think about that, so we should be careful how we phrase this)
- A note about confirming that `brew install apache-arrow --HEAD` completes successfully and how to confirm it's being picked up in the install process
- This might be part of the point above, but a description of what the difference/meaning of the following are: `*** Using Homebrew ${PKG_BREW_NAME`}, `*** Arrow C++ libraries found via pkg-config`, any mention of `autobrew`. Specifically, if one is trying to use homebrew for development, only the first one is ok, if someone sees something else that means that something isn't quite right.

comments.body:
***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14371?focusedCommentId=17430523) by Jonathan Keane (jonkeane):*
It looks like you've got a system-wide installation of libarrow which the installation process is picking up. Judging by the paths (`/usr/local/Cellar/apache-arrow/5.0.0_2`) This is actually a homebrew installation of the last release, which like the error message says, clashes with the current dev branch. Have you tried the advice below about `ARROW_USE_PKG_CONFIG`? Or when you installed `brew install apache-arrow --head` can you confirm that it's over-written this release install, and installed successfully?

```Java

*** Arrow C++ libraries found via pkg-config at
**** Warning: library version mismatch
**** C++ is 5.0.0 but R is 5.0.0.9000
**** If installation fails, upgrade the C++ library to match
**** or retry with ARROW_USE_PKG_CONFIG=false
```

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14371?focusedCommentId=17430534) by Dragoș Moldovan-Grünfeld (dragosmg):*
I've tried removing the C++ library and reinstalling it with brew. I still get an error.

How can I pass the ARROW_USE_PKG_CONFIG=false to R CMD INSTALL?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14371?focusedCommentId=17430537) by Jonathan Keane (jonkeane):*
Could you say more about how you did removed the C++ library and reinstalled it with brew? When you removed it, could you confirm that `/usr/local/Cellar/apache-arrow/5.0.0_2` no longer existed and could you try and confirm if `pkg-config` no longer has that listed?

`ARROW_USE_PKG_CONFIG=false` is an environment variable, so you can pass it like you would any other: 

```Java

ARROW_USE_PKG_CONFIG=false R CMD INSTALL .
```

```Java

export ARROW_USE_PKG_CONFIG=false 
R CMD INSTALL .
```

In an R session, though I don't think this is what you're doing:
```Java

Sys.setenv(ARROW_USE_PKG_CONFIG = "false")
install.packages("arrow")
```

I can confirm the `5.0.0_2` subdirectory no longer exists, just `5.0.0_4`.

I also figured it might be an environment variable (and didn't know how to pass it at the command line) so I edited my `.Renviron` file (which I think is being picked up irrespective of where the R session is started - command line or RStudio).

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14371?focusedCommentId=17430591) by Jonathan Keane (jonkeane):*
Ok, this is making progress, looks like we're successfully picking up the homebrew version. But we're still seeing a mismatch. There are two possible mismatches: 

- The version of the R package (e.g. your git clone of the arrow repo) could be out of date. To check this, could you tell me what is the git commit SHA of the checkout that you're using? Is it recent?  
- The version that brew installed might not have gotten installed correctly / in the right place. Could you show the output of when you run `brew install apache-arrow --HEAD`? Alternatively, if you look in `/usr/local/opt/apache-arrow/libs` what files do you see? You should see something like libarrow.600.0.0\* do you see that?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14371?focusedCommentId=17430594) by Dragoș Moldovan-Grünfeld (dragosmg):*

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14371?focusedCommentId=17430604) by Jonathan Keane (jonkeane):*
Ah ha! That looks like it's still the release version of libarrow. When I run `brew install apache-arrow --HEAD` I get:

```Java

jkeane@het ~ % brew install apache-arrow --HEAD   
[... homebrew updating]
==> Installing apache-arrow --HEAD
==> cmake ../cpp -DCMAKE_FIND_PACKAGE_PREFER_CONFIG=TRUE -DARROW_FLIGHT=ON -DARR

==> make install
==> Summary
🍺  /usr/local/Cellar/apache-arrow/HEAD-62ff659_4: 562 files, 132.3MB, built in 8 minutes 11 seconds
jkeane@het ~ % 
```

And then when I look in that directory, I'm seeing files marked 600:

```Java

jkeane@het apache-arrow % ls -lah /usr/local/Cellar/apache-arrow/HEAD-62ff659_4/lib
total 257744
...
-r--r--r--   1 jkeane  admin    20M Oct 19 10:15 libarrow.600.0.0.dylib
...
```

So it looks like where the install process is looking for libarrow is finding an old (release) version of libarrow still. Is it possible that when you ran `brew install apache-arrow --HEAD` there were linking errors? Could you try again and see what filepath it installs to and confirm that that has files in it that are **.600.**?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14371?focusedCommentId=17431187) by Jonathan Keane (jonkeane):*

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14371?focusedCommentId=17431290) by Jonathan Keane (jonkeane):*
Hmm, yeah something is up with brew identifying which python to use here. Let's open a separate Jira for this issue (or see if there's already one around, I looked briefly and didn't find anything) to see if we can update the brew formula for apache-arrow to not need something pre-installed like this. We can also tag folks who know better about packaging + python packaging there and get their help with what the right way to deal with this kind of mismatch is.
